Santilata runs her terracotta business with the help of her brother. She  learned this work in her childhood as it is their family occupation. She makes earthen pots and statues of gods and paints them. Her brother helps her to supply those finished products to the dealers in the market. 

She plans to expand her business, appoint new work staff to help her, and to own a shop in the marketplace for direct sale of the product to end customers. She needs a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to buy more resources like paints, brushes, and ornaments for statues (statue of Indian God and Goddess) and to set up her own shop in the market. 

She wants to give her niece and nephew a better education and let her family live a happy life.

loans.use: To pay for more clay and paints for her terracotta work and to set up her own shop in the market

loans.name: Manas

texts.en:
Manas is a 24-year-old physically challenged person living with this parents, his wife, and a one-year-old daughter in a small village of Odisha, India. He is a sculptor and has been involved in this rock sculpting work for the past five years. He makes idols of gods, goddesses, statues of animals and other dancing postures of nymphs. He learned this work in his school days when he became interested in it, and it has now become a source of income for his family. He earns 8,000 Indian Rupees (INR) from his carving work. 

He sells these statues to the retailers in the capital city of Odisha, i.e. Bhubaneswar. He has a plan to make a warehouse for keeping his statues so that he can protect them from weather. He has requested a loan of 30,000 INR to make a warehouse to store his finished statues and idols. With the remaining amount he plans to purchase more raw materials for making statues, and tools for carving them. He has a dream to give a good living standard to his family and save some money for his daughter's bright future.

loans.use: to pay for constructing a warehouse to store his finished statues and idols, and to buy raw materials for making statues.

loans.name: Manas

texts.en:
Manas, 29, is a physically challenged man living with his small family in Torasingh village in the state of Odisha, India. His family consists of his parents, younger brother and his wife. His father is into agriculture, and his younger brother helps his father in the fields. 

The main source of income for his family is paddy cultivation. Their living has been very unpredictable as weather might be favorable sometimes and not so other times. So, Manas wanted to supplement his father's income despite the limited opportunities he had due to physical disability and lack of education. He started a betel shop with the help of his father eight years ago as he saw a good opportunity for business. 

There are 100 families in his village and there are only three shops which can cater to their daily needs ranging from grocery items and snacks to mobile phone refill vouchers. So he started a betel shop selling food items like rice and cooking oil, packaged food like biscuits and cake, mobile refill vouchers, etc. He is helped by his father and brother to restock his inventory every three days from the nearby market. 

He has requested a loan of 50,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to purchase stock in bulk and repair his shop. He says that buying in bulk will avoid these frequent trips to the market and reduce his buying costs as well. He says that he likes the fact that he is helping the people in his village by providing their daily needs at a stone's throw. He wants to be able to provide more variety and to meet the demand of his customers to make his customers and eventually his family happy.

loans.use: to buy rice, cooking oil, packaged food items like biscuits, cake, mobile refill vouchers etc. in bulk for his shop.

loans.name: Ahalya

texts.en:
Ahalya is a 27-year-old single mother living with her six-year-old daughter in her father's house. She has been involved in the carpet-making business for the past 10 years: she gets raw materials from a dealer and supplies the finished goods to the same dealer for which she gets the labour cost. It takes one month to knit one carpet working four hours a day. She sells one carpet in a month and earns 2,500 Indian Rupees (INR) for one carpet (the price of the carpet depends on its size). 

She needs a loan of 25,000 INR to purchase her own raw materials for making carpets, i.e., wool and thread, so she can sell them in the market directly to the retailers. This way she can earn more as she can get the actual selling price for the carpet. She also plans to utilize a portion of the loan to buy the raw materials necessary for making incense sticks. She plans to divide her time between  making carpets and incense sticks as necessary. She will sell these incense sticks to shops in the nearby village market. 

Going forward she hopes to grow this business and hire two more additional staff to help her manage the business and create a living for other women like her in the village.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for making carpets and incense sticks

loans.name: Magi

texts.en:
Magi is a 44-year-old widow living with her three daughters and two sons in a village of Odisha, India. 

She has a small vegetable shop at her house from which she earns 700 Indian Rupee (INR) per month. Three of her children are studying and the other two had to drop out of school to help Magi in supporting their family. 

Her elder daughter who had to drop out of college to share her mother's burden started tutoring the kids in her village. They are able to make 3000 INR in a month even after her children's contribution. She is worried that her other three kids who are still in school might have to drop out as well if her financial situation does not improve. 

Her shop is the only shop for the 50 families living near her house in the village. She says that she feels good about making some daily household needs accessible to her customers without them having to travel far. 

She plans to start a grocery shop where she will sell grains, lentils, rice, wheat etc. for which she has requested a loan of 30,000 INR. She wants to utilize 40% of the loan to buy more rice and stock up for the monsoon season. There is a lot of demand for rice during this season as there is not enough stock available in the market. Magi's dream is to see her children continue school and give them a quality life.

loans.use: to buy grains, lentils, rice, wheat, and vegetables for her grocery store.

loans.name: Banamali

texts.en:
Banamali is a 60-year-old physically challenged person living with his wife, son, and daughter-in-law. He sells tea, biscuits, betel and wafers in his shop, earning 2,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

His son is a worker in a stone crushing factory. His son's job is to manually crush larger stones into smaller pieces with a hammer. These smaller pieces are then fed into a machine to make concrete. 

He wants to purchase a refrigerator to sell soft drinks and buy more stock and variety of biscuits, betel and wafers through which he says he can increase his sales and customer base as well. He also wants to buy some wooden furniture, like benches, to seat his new customers and keep his existing customers for a longer time at his shop and increase his sales. A lot of meetings in the village happen over tea at shops like these and having benches for them to sit at his shop will enable him to get more of such customers and keep them for a longer time at this shop. This will increase his sales for tea and other merchandise as well. 

He needs a loan of 25,000 INR for making these changes. With enough savings from the increased earnings he can make his dream of building a concrete house come true.

loans.use: to buy wooden furniture to seat his customers, a refrigerator to keep soft drinks, and more biscuits, betel and wafers for his shop.

loans.name: Nunthem Lom Group

texts.en: Lamneng is 33 years old, unmarried, and lives with her parents and two nephews, whose parents passed away. She is the sole breadwinner. She weaves traditional clothes with a handloom. Her earnings are utilized for the upkeep of the family. She wants to take a loan to purchase two more handlooms and impart training to make more money. During the off season, when there is less demand for traditional clothes, she engages herself in selling secondhand clothes, which are in high demand among low-income groups.

loans.use: To purchase two more handlooms

loans.name: Jayanti

texts.en:
Jayanti is a 38-year-old woman living with her husband and two daughters in Odisha, India. Her husband is ill, so he is unable to go outside and work to earn a livelihood. 

Jayanti is a very hardworking and responsible woman. She has taken on all the burdens and responsibilities of her family. She earns money by maintaining the account books of different self-help groups in the locality. Self-help groups are those groups formed for microfinance loans. She also does some tailoring and stitches dresses for her neighbors. Her daughters are studying in school. She has been struggling to provide basic needs for her family, support her sick husband, and send her children to a good school from the limited income she is earning from these varied jobs. 

She has a plan to set up a new business of making paper plates in her house for which she has requested a loan amount of 30,000 Indian Rupee (INR). She learned this activity from her parents, she says that "I would be able to earn more after setting up this business, and give my daughters a quality education and see them independent".

loans.use: to set up a new business of making paper plates in her house.

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Sunita is a 28-year-old single mother living with her four-year-old daughter and her parents. She got separated from her husband due to some personal reaons. She does not want to become a burden on her father so she started the business of making beedis (Indian cigarettes filled with tobacco flakes and wrapped in tendu leaves). A local dealer supplies her raw materials and takes back the end product, paying her the labour cost. Her job is to roll the tendu leaves into a cigarette shape and fill them with tobacco flakes. She spends seven to eight hours per day making six bundles of beedis (each bundle contains 25 beedis). She is paid 1500 Indian Rupees (INR) per month on average depending on the number of beedis she rolls. 

She now plans to get raw material on her own and sell them directly to the retailers so that she can get the actual selling price of the beedis. She has requested a loan amount of 10,000 INR for purchasing raw materials like tobacco and tendu leaves. She wants to save enough to send her daughter to a good school and see her daughter become independent.

loans.use: to buy raw materials like tobacco and tendu leaves for making beedis (Indian cigarettes filled with tobacco flakes and wrapped in tendu leaves).

loans.name: Mili

texts.en:
Mili is a 25-year-old differently-abled girl staying with her parents and her younger brother and sister. Her father, Jugal, is a contractor who takes small orders for building village roads. He supports his family by doing this work. 

Having a very independent personality, Mili does not want to depend on her father and wants to have her own source of income. She knows that her father will not always be there to support her. As a physically challenged person, it is not possible for her to do hard labor. So she got trained in making incense sticks. Currently, she is involved in an incense stick business where she makes them at home and sells them to a nearby shop in the village, earning 200 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

She plans to start a ladies novelty corner of her own in the nearby market in the village. She will sell ladies' cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo, body talc, body deodorant, and incense sticks as well. She requires a loan of 30,000 INR to set up a shop of her own and make her dreams of making a living for herself come true.

loans.use: to pay for setting up a ladies novelty store and purchasing stock like cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo, body talc, body deodorant, and incense sticks

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Sabitri is a 36-year-old widow who lives in Odisha, India along with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, two sons and one daughter. Her three children are studying. She is a very hard-working lady. She is currently involved in three different activities to support her family. 

She works as an attendant (service person) at a kindergarten school from 9 AM to 1 PM. She returns home after that to make papad from different varieties of lentils like black gram till 5 PM in the evening, selling it to her neighbors. Papad is a local popular side dish that are round and eaten fried in oil/roasted over a fire or added to curries for flavor. She makes them during the day as she needs the sunlight to dry them out to make them ready to fry for selling once she rolls the dough into thin rounds. Later in the day, after 5 PM she makes plates woven out of dry leaves at her house and sells them to a nearby hotel. These plates are biodegradable, disposable, hygienic, and an inexpensive alternative to modern paper or plastic utensils. 

She wants to do this business of making leaf plates and papad at a larger scale and make it her profession. She wants to be able to make more leaf plates and supply them for local functions in which food is served and make more papad and sell it to shops in the market. She says that she needs to buy more leaves in the summer and stock up during the monsoon season during which the dry leaves are a scarcity. 

She has requested a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to purchase the raw materials like leaves for the plates and other resources like lentils, rice, and oil for the papad business. 

She can give more time to her children and family if she can be involved more in this business and quit her other job at the school. She wants to give the best education to her children and a good quality of life to her family.

loans.use: to buy raw materials like leaves for making plates, and other resources like lentils, rice, oil for her papad business.

loans.name: Akshaya

texts.en:
Akshaya is an ambitious 26-year-old single man living with his parents. He is a differently abled man who has a mobile repairing and soft drinks shop. 

He sells mobile phone parts like panels and key pads, as well as mobile accessories and soft drinks in his shop. He can meet the basic repairing needs of a customer. But for advanced repairs he has to travel to the nearest balugaon (a village in Odisha, India) market to purchase the mobile repairing parts/materials like display, keypad as and when a customer comes. He wants to be able to give the best service to his customers from his village with as little turnaround time as possible and capture the business opportunity, as his shop is the only shop in the village that provides these services currently. 

He wants to now buy and stock up such advanced repairing materials at his shop to avoid the travel, and he says that buying at bulk will help him reduce buying costs as well. He needs a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to buy these parts and hire one more staff member to help him around the shop. In the future, he wants to expand his business and open a big private company and create a living for other people like him.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone parts like panels, key pads, accessories, and advanced repair materials, and to hire staff

loans.name: Ashma

texts.en:
Ashma is a 21-year-old unmarried physically challenged woman. She is a determined individual who works hard to support her family's basic needs and brother's education. She lives with her parents and her younger brother. She owns a variety store at her house and sells cosmetics, shampoos, soaps, bangles etc. through this shop earning 10,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

She requested a loan of 20,000 INR to buy more cosmetics and bangles, things that she is already selling, and also some additional products like detergents, chocolates, wafers and stationery items. She hopes to increase her business to give her family a better quality of life and send her younger brother to a good school.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, bangles, shampoos, detergents, chocolates, wafers and stationery items for her store.

loans.name: Laxmipriya

texts.en:
Laxmipriya is a 27-year-old woman living with her two children aged 8 and 10. They are going to school. She was happily married to Mr. Abhimanyu until she lost her husband in an accident four years back. Since then she has been working hard to make ends meet, starting a tailoring business at her home. She was involved in this business before her marriage as well and has known this trade for the last 10 years. She currently owns one sewing machine and has trained some girls in her village for money. 

She needs a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to buy two more sewing machines and hire the trainees as her staff to help her in taking more orders from the customers and delivering better service to them. She also wants to buy some furniture like wooden racks to keep the stitched and unstitched clothes as she sees an increased amount of work and demand from customers with these expansions in place. Her dream is to give her children a better education and a quality life.

loans.use: to buy two sewing machines and wooden racks, and to hire staff

loans.name: Prashant

texts.en:
Prashant is a 40-year-old differently-abled person. He is living with his wife and eight-year-old daughter who is attending school. Unfortunately, he met with an accident while trying to get to the other side of the road and lost his left hand in 2010. He lost his 13-year-old son in the same accident. He could not continue his job as an employee at the state government electricity board and started a grocery shop in his house in the same year. He is the only earning person in his family and this business has been supporting his family. In this shop he sells items like rice, cooking oil, sugar, soap, hair oil, etc. 

There are 250 potential customers in his village but he is unable to meet the customer demand. He needs to travel to the nearest market in the village with the help of his brother to refill his stock every day, depending on the demand, as he does not have funds to maintain inventory levels sufficient even for a week. 

He wants to buy a fridge for ice cream and to purchase goods which he sells in his grocery shop, like rice, oil, sugar etc., in bulk. He can decrease his stock refilling rate, transportation costs and buying costs. He can meet the demand and earn more from his business which will help him to control his daily cash flow. He hopes to send his daughter to a good school and give his family a better standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a fridge for ice cream and to purchase rice, oil, sugar etc. in bulk for his grocery shop.

loans.name: Manjulata

texts.en:
Manjulata is a 40-year-old differently-abled hardworking lady. She got married to Mr. Birakishor in 1991. She is living with her husband and two daughters who are attending school/college. 

Manjulata makes local food items like papad (crackers) and badi (fried) from different varieties of lentils like black gram. Her husband goes to different villages from house to house to sell these items. These are local popular side dishes that are round and eaten fried in oil/roasted over a fire or added to curries for flavor. She grinds the lentils and makes dough by adding other ingredients like rice, salt, oil, water and desired seasonings. She then rolls the dough into thin rounds and dries them in the sun to make them ready to fry for selling. She spends seven to eight hours a day at these activities. It is her determination to see her daughters well-educated that has been getting her through this hard manual labor despite her disability. 

She wants to take a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to buy a grinder that runs on electricity. This will let her grind the lentils and make her life much easier. She also wants to buy more raw materials like lentils (black gram), rice, oil, onions and garlic to make more of these items and sell in bulk to shops in the village market. 

She wants to give a better education to her daughters, and get them married in a good family.

loans.use: to buy an electronic grinder and raw materials like lentils, rice, oil, onions and garlic for making papads and badis

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Sabitri is an unmarried and physically challenged lady aged 36. At present she lives with her mother and younger brother. Unfortunately her father passed away twelve years ago. Her younger brother is the only wage earner for her family. Her brother's income is not enough for her family. Sabitri says that her financial condition is very poor. If she can get some financial support, she will invest in a utensils shop. She is going to sell aluminum pots and pans for cooking. 

She has experience in the utensil business for the last three years as she was helping her brother who sells utensils on a push cart (a mobile utensils shop). Sabitri now wants to utilize those business skills she has acquired and do same business at her home and generate additional revenue for her family and ensure her mother is taken care of as her brother might not be able to support them in the future due to additional responsibilities of his family after his marriage. She needs a loan of 40,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to start her own aluminum utensils business at home.

loans.use: to set up her own aluminum utensils business at home.

loans.name: Sharat

texts.en:
Sharat, a differently abled person, aged 30, is married and lives with his wife and three children. He resides in Odisha, India. He worked as an insurance agent until he lost his hand in a fireworks accident five years ago. Sharat has been operating a variety store at the village market to earn a living and support his family. He sells detergents, chocolates, noodles, soft drinks and other daily use necessities for the household in his shop. He earns 7,000 Indian Rupees (INR). 

His shop is close to a school and a playground. The part that he likes most about his job is the interaction with the school children who remind him of his children. 

He requested a loan of 30,000 INR to purchase additional products like stationery, wafers, hair oil and shampoo to meet the needs of the school children and the village youth who come there to play in the playground. In the future, Sharat wants to enhance his business and see that his children complete their education and give them a better life than what he has now.

loans.use: to buy stationery, wafers, hair oil and shampoo for his grocery store.

loans.name: Mamata

texts.en:
Mamata is a single mother, who lives with her father and son aged 16. Her son is attending college. Hers is the only source of income for her family. Mamata sells bangles, nail polish, and gold-plated jewelry items. She has been in the business of selling cosmetics and jewelry for six years. 

She is applying for a loan to buy more plated jewelry and beauty products such as make-up, lipsticks and creams, in order to improve and enrich the business through the availability of more variety of products to meet customer demand. 

This loan will help her improve her sales and enable her to offer a new product line to her customers. Her objective is to expand the business and include new products, such as clothing, to her existing business. She wants to save for her son's education with the increased revenues from the increased sales supported by the variety in products.

loans.use: to buy more plated jewelry and beauty products such as make-up, lipsticks and creams for her shop.

loans.name: Benu

texts.en:
Benu is fifty-three and married. He lives with his wife and three children aged 24, 22 and 19. He was working at a garment factory as a daily laborer away from his home until he met with an accident while working. The physical condition of his legs did not permit him to continue work there. His physical disability limited the kind of work he can do. Since then his wife and his elder son have been working hard to support the family. His elder son had to drop out of school to work as a day laborer in the paddy fields. 

He wants to start a vegetable shop near the market and generate revenue to increase cash flows for his family despite his disability. He requested a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to make a cabin (a house for his vegetable shop) and to purchase the vegetables. The earnings from his business will help him to strengthen his economic status and provide the basic needs for his family.

loans.use: to buy a cabin (a house for his vegetable shop) and vegetables for his shop.

loans.name: Jhuni

texts.en:
Jhuni is a 33-year-old widow living with two daughters and one son. She has two years experience in tailoring. After her husband's death she opened a tailoring shop at her house and started earning her livelihood and supporting her children's education. She has one sewing machine currently and her sister assists her in the business. 

She says there is an opportunity for the growth of her business as her shop is the only tailoring shop in the village. But due to lack of funds she is not able to expand her business. She requires a loan amount of 30,000 Indian Rupees (INR) for purchasing additional sewing machine and fabrics to meet the demand and make her customers happy. 

She hopes to give her children a good education. She also intends to expand her workplace as much as she can, train some girls from her village, and hire them as help, creating a living for them as well.

loans.use: to buy additional sewing machine and fabrics for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Sabita is a 20-year-old divorced lady who lives with her mother and father. She has a small grocery shop in her house where she sells lentils, rice, edible oil, spices, salt and biscuits. She earns 2,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month from her shop which is not enough for a family of three. She is the only one to support her family. 

She has requested a loan of 30,000 INR for purchasing more rice, lentils, oil, spices etc. and add for adding new product lines to her shop like cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo sachets, and detergents to meet her customers' demand and make them highly satisfied. She hopes to build a separate shop outside her house and take good care of her parents.

loans.use: to buy more rice, lentils, oil, spices etc. and new products like cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo sachets, and detergents to her shop.

loans.name: Bijay

texts.en:
Bijay is 50 years old and married to Rina. They have two daughters and one son, who they care for with love and dedication in their own home located in Odisha, India. 

He was a heavy vehicle driver in Delhi, India. He lost his job when he was became ill. He pulls a rented trolley-rickshaw to support his family. He uses this trolley-rickshaw to carry waste products like polythene, iron, discarded glass/plastic bottles and sells them to a local scrap dealer. In this way he earns 4000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month and pays 25% of this income towards monthly rent of the trolley-rickshaw. 

Bijay requested a loan of 15,000 INR through People's Forum to purchase his own trolley-rickshaw. He can save the rent amount and use it to repay the loan that he has asked for and become the owner of trolley-rickshaw in no time. In this way he can strengthen his earning capacity and support his family and see his children get a better education.

loans.use: to buy his own trolley-rickshaw.

loans.name: Chanchala

texts.en:
Chanchala is a 34-year-old widow living with her mother-in-law and two sons aged 12 and 4. Her sons are attending school. She has been running a tailoring shop at her house for the past five years. She currently has two sewing machines and stitches dresses and bags for multipurpose use like to carry luggage, to carry for travelling, and for school-going children. She has contracts with local sellers in the market who come and collect the finished bags from her. She earns 6,000 Indian Rupees (INR) monthly from this business. 

She needs a loan of 30,000 INR for purchasing two new sewing machines and fabrics and to hire a workforce to help her with the additional work. She also plans to use a portion of her loan to build a separate room from her house where she can run her tailoring business as she says that it will not be convenient to run her growing business in the house with her sons studying. She hopes to have her sons go to a good school and save enough to see them become engineers.

loans.use: to buy two sewing machines and fabrics and to hire a workforce to help her with the additional work.

loans.name: Khupting Lom Group

texts.en:
Tingneineng, also affectionately called Nengboi (the lady who is raising her hand in the photo) is 31 years of age. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a carpenter. She always wishes to educate her children and give them better living conditions. Her husband’s earnings are inadequate to meet all these necessities. 

Last year, she took a loan from WSDS and started weaving traditional clothes to generate more income for the family. She sells her finished products on the market days. Her weaving business is very successful. Besides taking care of her household needs, she manages to repay her loan on time. 

She now wants to purchase more thread for weaving traditional shawls in large quantity to be able to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: to purchase more thread for weaving traditional shawls

loans.name: Swapna

texts.en:
Swapna is 35-year-old widow staying with her three daughters aged 14, 11 and 8. All are attending school. She was living with her husband and three daughters until her husband died from an unknown disease three years ago. Since then she has been working hard to take care of her daughters and send them to school. She started a small shop where she has been selling rice, kerosene (cooking and lighting fuel, also used as fuel for fishing boats), whisk brooms and vegetables for the past three years. Her brother-in-law helps her in running the business. Fifty-eight families in her village are benefitting from the shop as they do not need to travel far to access these items. 

Rice comprises the majority of her merchandise as she had to discontinue selling vegetables due to the steep hike in the price of vegetables in spite of good demand. She sells 600 kg of rice per month to the people in her village including those fishermen who go away from home for days to fish. There is more demand for rice in the village but she is not able to meet the demand. She is currently earning 2000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month 

She has requested a loan of 10,000 INR so that she can purchase four bags (50 kg) of rice, kerosene and vegetables. She wants to start selling vegetables again as she has enough funds to buy the pricey vegetables and meet the demand for vegetables in the village She says she can increase her cash flows by 100% to 4000 INR per month with these changes. This way she can plan for her daughters' education and save enough for her elder daughter's marriage.

loans.use: to buy rice, kerosene and vegetables for her grocery store.

loans.name: Pandab

texts.en:
Pandab is a resident of the sacred town of Puri, the home of Lord Jagannath in Odisha. He is 57 years old and lives with his wife, who is ill. He has been supporting his family through the income earned from a small general store. He sells food items like snacks, spices, electric bulbs, and soda in his village. He has had it for the last eight years. 

He needs a loan for 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) in order to buy more snacks, spices, soda and other household necessities like toilet cleaners, mosquito repellents and wafers for his shop. He says there is good demand for mosquito repellents and sanitizers as mosquito borne diseases are very widely prevalent in his village. He wants to increase his income and provide his wife better medication and quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more snacks, spices, soda, and other household necessities like toilet cleaners, mosquito repellents and wafers for his general store

loans.name: Manjari

texts.en:
Manjari is 32-year-old divorced lady who lives with her parents and her two daughters aged five and seven. Both of them are going to school. She runs a snacks business. She cooks the snacks at home and her father roams on his bicycle on the busy streets of the market and door to door to sell the snacks. 

She goes to sleep at 10 p.m. at night, wakes up early in the morning at one a.m. every day to cook snacks like samosas (fried dough stuffed with potato curry), idli, wada etc. and sweets like jalebi till 6 a.m., when her father leaves the house with these snacks and roams, selling them, till 5:00 in the evening. She sells a small portion of the snacks at her house as well. During the day she rests for two hours and then starts making leaf plates woven out of dry leaves at her house. These are used as plates in which they can sell their snacks. She earns 4000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

Manjari has applied for a loan of 25,000 INR to purchase raw materials like wheat, spices, cooking oil, besan (gram flour), maida (finely milled and refined wheat flour) etc. in bulk, as well as utensils for cooking. She also wants to buy some furniture like wooden benches to seat her customers at the house. She wants to make more as her father says that he can sell more in the busier streets of the market. She can increase her revenues by 50%, earning 5500 to 6000 INR per month. This will help her to save enough to send her daughters to school. She hopes to make enough to have a shop in the market where she can make and sell these snacks instantly. She says this will make their lives easier and give her enough time to spend with her kids as she need not wake up at midnight to cook and her father need not roam on a bicycle.

loans.use: to buy wooden benches and raw materials like wheat, spices, cooking oil, flour, and utensils for cooking for her snacks shop.

loans.name: Gopal

texts.en:
Gopal is 32 years old and married. He has two daughters aged 10 and 12 who are attending school. His father is ill, so all of his family members are depending on him. He is the only income provider for his family. 

Gopal works hard to provide the basic needs for his family. He runs a general store in his village in the state of Odisha. He has been running the general store for 16 years and earns an income from his business. He sells items like rice, lentils, spices, wafers etc. through this shop. 

He requested a loan of 50,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to buy more stock and variety of lentils, spices and rice that he currently sells. He says that his business expansion can earn him good returns. He hopes to build a concrete house for his family and send his children to English medium school.

loans.use: To buy more stock and variety of lentils, spices and rice that he currently sells.

loans.name: Bideshi

texts.en:
Bideshi is 35 years of age and lives with his mother, wife, and his 10-year-old daughter who is attending school. His mother has been ill and needs his support. He has a grocery shop in his village where he sells rice, grains, edible oil, spices, biscuits, soap, detergent, hair oil etc. He has developed a good relationship with his neighbors through this shop. He has been running this shop from the age of 17 as he lost his father at a very young age. He worked hard to start his own business and support his family as it was difficult for him to find a job, and his family relies on his support.

He wants to reinvest in his business to buy more stock of what he sells and increase his inventory level as buying in bulk will reduce his buying and transportation costs and help him reach out to more customers. 

Bideshi has requested a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to buy more rice, oil, and other daily household items that he sells in his shop. He says the profits of his grocery shop will help him provide his family with basic needs and allow his daughter to go to a good school.

loans.use: to buy more rice, oil and other daily household items that he sells in his shop.

loans.name: Kanaka

texts.en:
Kanaka is a 52-year-old married woman living with her husband and her two sons. Her husband is ill, but he supports his family by pulling a trolley-rickshaw. A trolley-rickshaw is generally used to carry scrap material or for luggage transportation. Her younger son has had a salon for the last two years and the other son is working at a local hotel as a waiter. 

She needs a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) from People's Forum to purchase a rotating chair, mirrors and other accessories for her son's salon to make it as attractive and competent as the other shops in the village and increase the number of customers coming to the shop. 

She aspires to earn more money through the increased facilities in the shop which will not only provide the basic needs for her family but also enable her to share the burden of her sick husband.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing a rotating chair, mirrors and other accessories for her son’s salon.

loans.name: Ganesh

texts.en:
Ganesh is a 22-year-old unmarried man living with his parents and a younger brother aged 19. His father is ill and his brother is studying, so his earnings are the only source of income in the family. He owns a small grocery store at his house where he sells detergents, shampoos, spices, toffees, wafers and oil, earning 5,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

Ganesh has been working hard to take care of his sick father and send his brother to college. He does not want his brother to drop out of college for financial reasons. He wants to ensure that he earns enough to save enough to send his brother to college and see him get a good government job. 

He has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to purchase a refrigerator to sell soft drinks and water. With the remaining amount he plans to buy more stock and a variety of spices, oil, personal care merchandise like shampoos, detergents, and toothpaste, which he is selling right now. He also wants to add more varieties of chocolates and wafers.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator, spices, oil, shampoos, detergents, and toothpaste for his grocery shop

loans.name: Sulochana

texts.en:
Sulochana is 38 years of age and is married to Kalia, who is a mason. She lives with her husband and 11-year-old daughter. She is very well known in her neighborhood as she loves talking to people. 

Sulochana has been ill since 2007 and was unable to find regular work since then. So she purchased five goat kids to take care of them and sell them for meat when they grow. Now she owns eight goats and wants to purchase more kids and sell them when they grow. It takes eight to nine months for her to make them ready to sell. She goes out in the morning to leave the goats to graze in the fields and returns by noon. She is then involved in household activities and resumes taking care of her goats by feeding them at home. Her husband assists her in selling and maintaining these goats. 

She says that there is a lot of demand during the local festive and Indian wedding seasons. Currently she is not able to meet the demand during these months and other peak demand times. She wants to take out a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to purchase some goat kids to be able to sell more and seize the opportunity during this peak demand period. She wants to see her daughter become educated and independent.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing more goat kids to meet customer demand during peak demand period.

loans.name: Lingaraj

texts.en:
Lingaraj is a 60-year-old physically challenged person living with his wife and a 24-year-old son who is deaf. He sells popular Indian street snacks like jhalmuri (prepared from mixing puffed rice, boiled potato, tomato, sprouts, onion, red chili powder, and salt). He roams around on his tricycle on the busy streets of the market selling it. He spends seven to eight hours roaming on his tricycle to sell and make enough to feed his family. His son does not have a regular job and is a mason who works whenever he gets work from construction projects going on in the village. 

Lingaraj now wants to open a shop in a good location in the market to run his snacks business. He says that it will make his life easier as he does not need to roam on his tricycle all day to make his living. He also wants to sell more of what he is selling with the help of his son. This way he feels that his son can earn a regular income and also share the burden of the family. 

He has requested a loan of 15,000 Indian Rupee (INR) for setting up a shop where he can sell jhalmuri sitting at one place and for purchasing more stock of what he sells. He has a dream to make a concrete house and replace his mud house.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients and set up a shop where he can sell jhalmuri (an Indian snack food)

loans.name: Saria

texts.en:
Saria is a 56-year-old married woman living with her husband and her 19-year-old son. She is a hardworking person and has developed a good rapport with her neighbors through her small business. She runs a betel shop with the support of her husband, who is a security guard. She sells incense sticks, detergents, bathing soaps, hair oil, toothpaste, toothbrushes etc. 

Saria is an active woman, although she has been ill. She works hard to provide an education for her son who is going to college right now. She needs to refill her stock every three days by travelling to the nearest wholesale market in the village. 

Saria requested a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupees (INR) through which she will purchase soap, detergents, hair oil, and toothpaste in greater quantity and variety for her shop. This will help her to reduce her transportation and buying costs, increasing her margin on the merchandise. She aspires to save enough money to afford to put her son through college and see him become an engineer.

loans.use: to buy soap, detergents, hair oil, and toothpaste for her shop.

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
Sumitra is 28-year-old lady staying with her three sons, a three-year-old and two-year-old twins. She lives in a village close to the beautiful Chilika lake; one of the biggest lakes in Odisha. Fishermen of the nearby villages are depending on this lake for their livelihood.

Sumitra got married to Debendra Jali in 2007. Like any other village folk, her husband was a fisherman who went to Chilika for fishing. Unfortunately, she lost her husband in 2011 in an accident when he went for fishing. Since then she has been working hard to support her children. She started the business of selling fresh fish and dry fish. Drying the fish is a way of preserving the fish for future use by drying them in the sun until water is completely evaporated. Dried fish has a storage life of several years. Dried fish is used in different delicacies as fresh fish is and is very popular in the region. 

She buys fish directly from the local fishermen and sells some of them fresh and dries some of them to sell as dried fish. She purchases and sells 10 to 12 kg of fresh fish and 18-20 kg of dried fish by roaming door to door in the nearby villages. She earns 3500 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. 

She has applied for a loan of 20,000 INR so that she can purchase the fish in a bulk amount to make more dried fish and stock up during the monsoon season. There is a huge demand for dried fish during the monsoon season as not much stock is available in the market. So, she can get a better price as well. This loan will help her increase the working capital to run her business, increasing her revenues by almost 50% giving 5000 to 6000 INR per month. 

She wants to save enough to give her three children a good quality of life and send them to school. She wants to see them educated, working at MNCs and not as fishermen.

loans.use: to buy fish in bulk for drying and selling during the monsoon season.

loans.name: Kahnu Charan

texts.en:
Kahnu Charan is aged forty-two and expert in bamboo works. He is married with five children, two of whom are still in school. Unfortunately his right leg was damaged in an accident. For this reason he cannot do work that involves a lot of physical strain. 

Kahnu Charan has been engaged in bamboo work for the last thirty years. He makes different bamboo items like baskets to hold articles to be offered to god, which is used in the Jagannath Temple of Puri in eastern Odisha, and decorative items for household purpose. 

Kahnu Charan has requested a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) from People's Forum to buy bamboo in bulk which will help to produce more finished products. He says the profit of his business will help to strengthen his financial status. He can fulfill the necessities of his children's education.

loans.use: to buy bamboo in bulk for making bamboo baskets

loans.name: Madhusudan

texts.en:
Madhusudan is a 41-year-old physically challenged person. He lives with his wife, son aged 14, and a daughter aged 7. His wife is a housewife and both his children are attending school. He has been running a small tea and betel shop in his village located in the state of Odisha, India for the past 10 years. He sells tea, betel, biscuits, toffees, wafers and tobacco sachets in his shop. He earns 3,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month from his shop. 

He has a plan to make his shop bigger and add some more stock of what he sells. He also wants to buy a refrigerator to keep other products like soft drinks and chocolates in his shop. 

He has asked for a loan of 20,000 INR for making his shop bigger and purchasing the above mentioned items. He has a dream for his daughter study in a good school and his son to graduate from a nice college, so that both his children can have a bright future.

loans.use: to enlarge his shop and buy more betel, biscuits, wafers, tobacco sachets and also a refrigerator to keep soft drinks and chocolates

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Sabitri is a 38-year-old woman living with her two children. Her two children aged 8 and 10 are attending school. She left her husband for some personal reasons. She has been working as a daily laborer since then to manage her family all by herself. 

She recently started a small tea stall through which she has been selling tea for the last two years. She wants to grow her business into a food stall. She has a plan to sell some local snacks like samosas (fried dough stuffed with potato curry), idlis (a popular recipe of south Indian origin made by steaming a batter consisting of fermented black lentils and rice), wadas (lentil doughnuts), and so on in addition to tea through her shop. She has her shop in front of her house which makes it easy to look after her children as well as the shop. 

She requested a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to purchase the cooking utensils and raw materials like flour, oil, and spices for her snacks shop. She says the additional source of income will enable her to be financially stronger and provide a good education to her children.

loans.use: to buy resources like cooking utensils and raw materials like flour, oil, and spices for her snacks shop.

loans.name: T.gamdeiphai Lom Group

texts.en:
Nemjahat (the one raising her right hand in the photo) has six children, three girls and three boys. She purchases used clothes from wholesalers and resells them in the market. 

She wants to continue her business and increase her sales.To be able to purchase more clothes in large volume, she is asking for a loan of INR 10,000.

loans.use: to buy more used clothing for resale.

loans.name: Tikina

texts.en:
Tikina is a 35-year-old single mother living with her parents, son aged 9, and daughter aged 14. She got married to Mr. Babuli in 1997 and got separated from her husband after six years for personal reasons. Since then she has been staying with her parents. She wanted to be independent and started a business. She sells ladies garments like sarees, blouses and dresses for kids etc. roaming from door to door in the nearby villages. She travels 15-20 km by foot in one day selling her merchandise. She earns 2000 to 2500 Indian Rupees (INR) per month from this business. 

Tikina wants to set up a garment shop in the village market so that she can avoid traveling so much and get more time to spend with her children. She requires money to purchase the clothes in larger amounts and new varieties according to market demand. She wants to purchase a wide variety of sarees and other clothing for women as well as kids. 

Tikina has requested a loan of 25,000 INR to set up a garment shop in the market. She says that she can earn 4000 to 5000 INR from this shop of her own and she can send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to set up a garment shop in the market and to buy clothing for women and children.

loans.name: Prema

texts.en:
Prema is an optimistic and determined woman. She is 56 years of age and happily married to Kumbha. Unfortunately her husband is ill, so she is the only earning member of her family. It was really hard for her to manage her family in the beginning when her husband became ill. But as the days passed by, she became able to abide these things through the guidance of our God Almighty. 

She took to the idea of bamboo crafting because she was engaged in this work in her childhood. She is currently doing this business and she makes different bamboo products like bamboo baskets, flower vases, pen stands, etc. and sells them in the market. 

Now she wants a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupee (INR) to purchase bamboo in bulk for making large quantities of baskets, flower vases and other products to  increase her revenues. She will be able to earn a good income to support her husband and see her dreams of building her own house come true.

loans.use: to buy bamboo in bulk for making bamboo baskets, flower vases, pen stands, etc.

loans.name: Sebati

texts.en:
Sebati is 36-year-old widow living with her two children. She has a daughter who is doing graduation and a son who is a driver. She has been working hard to support her daughter's education and give her children a good life since her husband passed away. 

She currently runs a betel shop where she sells betel, tobacco sachets, biscuits, toffees etc. and wants to grow her business. She wants to take a loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to purchase other items like snacks, chocolates, wafers, noodles etc. to sell in her shop. 

She requested a loan from People's Forum to enhance her business, save some money for her daughter's marriage ceremony, and make her son's future bright.

loans.use: to buy betel, tobacco sachets, biscuits, toffees and some other additional products like snacks, chocolates, wafers, noodles etc. for her shop.

loans.name: Sandhya Rani

texts.en:
Sandhya rani is a 28-year-old lady. She left her husband due to some personal reasons. Currently, she is staying with her parents, three brothers, and her six-year-old daughter in a small village of Odisha, India. She is supporting her family business which is to sell terracotta statues and masks. 

She has 10 years of experience in terracotta now. She sells these statues and masks in the nearby market; her brothers assist her in supplying the finished product to the market. She supplies her products to the retailers in the capital city of Odisha, i.e., Bhubaneswar, and she also sells her products by the roadside at the time of some festivals. She wants to earn enough to save for her daughter's bright future. 

She requested a loan of 30,000 Indian Rupee (INR) for purchasing clay, paints, and brushes and growing her business. She hopes to send her daughter to a better school and provide her a better education.

loans.use: to buy clay, paints, and brushes for making statues and masks.

loans.name: Lili

texts.en:
Lili is a 31-year-old widow who lives with her three children in the village of Soran, Odisha. She was a happy wife and mother until she lost her husband in 2007. Since then she has been struggling to raise her two daughters aged 8 and 10 and one son aged 13. They are all attending school. She started a photo studio in a good location in the market of her village with the help of her brother-in-law three years ago. She earns 4,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month, which has been the only source of income for her to give her three children a good life. 

She provides a variety of services like digital passport size photographs, full sized photographs and video shoots for various auspicious ceremonies like weddings and other functions in her village and the four surrounding it. She says that showing people looking beautiful and happy, and being part of their happy moments to provide those memories, is what she likes the most about her work. She has earned a good name for her studio by providing quality work. 

Taking her interest further in showing people looking beautiful, she wants to start a garment store in a room adjacent to her studio. She sees a good opportunity for business as there is no other garment store in the village, and also a good demand from her existing customer base. She needs a loan to purchase the necessary stock like sarees, blouses, clothes for kids and girls, and to pay the necessary deposits to rent out the room.

loans.use: to buy sarees, blouses, dresses for kids and girls and to set up a garment store.

loans.name: Panchei

texts.en:
Panchei is a 32-year-old divorced lady living with her father and mother. Presently she works in a cashew factory as a daily laborer. She gets only 60 Indian Rupees (INR) per day which is not sufficient for her family to arrange for the basic necessities of life. Her father has a small snacks shop where he sells samosas (fried dough stuffed with potato curry), idlis (a steamed batter consisting of fermented black lentils and rice), and wadas (lentil doughnuts) from which he earns 70-100 INR per day. She wants to help her father in his business and make his shop bigger. 

She has applied for a loan of 30,000 INR so that she can purchase ingredients like besan (gram flour), spices, oil, salt, potatoes, lentils etc. for making snacks in bulk. She also wants to purchase ingredients like like maida (wheat flour), sugar, dry fruits etc. for making sweets in her father's shop. Panchei says that she will resign from her daily labor work, because she thinks that she does not get paid enough for her work of 10 hours, and help her father full time in growing the snacks business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like besan (gram flour), spices, oil, salt, potato, and lentils for making snacks in her snacks shop.

loans.name: Kusumalata

texts.en:
Kusumalata is a 41-year-old widow, living with her widowed younger sister and her two nieces. She earns her livelihood by doing tailoring work, taking orders from customers and stitching dresses for them. She lives in her sister's house and does not want to be a burden on her, so she started this tailoring work to support her sister financially. 

At present she has two sewing machines which are not sufficient to meet customer demand. She plans to purchase five new sewing machines and start a tailoring workshop where she will train others, thus having more staff to help meet the increasing customer demand. She has requested a loan of 35,000 Indian Rupees (INR) for purchasing new sewing machines and fabric. 

She has a dream to enable her nieces to study in a good school and give them all the facilities they need.

loans.use: to buy five new sewing machines and start a tailoring workshop.

loans.name: Zion Lom Group

texts.en:
Lalnunmawi (the lady raising her hand in the photo) is 41 years old. She lives with her two school-going daughters. The older daughter, on completion of her schooling, wishes to pursue a nursing course. 

To fulfill her daughter’s cherished dream, Lalnunmawi works very hard. She is into the secondhand clothes business. She normally purchases used clothes (secondhand) from the wholesalers and resells them by the roadside at the market. 

Sometimes she moves around (door-to-door) with the bundles of secondhand clothing to sell. This happens as per the request and demands of the customers. 

Besides, she weaves traditional and customary clothing with a handloom, only at nighttime, to generate extra income.

loans.use: to purchase used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Laileng Lom Group

texts.en:
Tinga lives in Keithelmanbi, Manipur, India, with five children. She does seasonal vegetable farming on her small plot of land. These vegetables are sold in the village market. Besides, she rears piglets and a good number of chickens to generate extra income for the family. 

Like many other parents, she also wants to educate all her children and give them a better living. For this, she toils day in and day out, putting in her best effort just for the sake of her children. 

She would like to boost her vegetable business and requests a loan.

loans.use: to purchase a large quantity of vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Venghoi Lom Group

texts.en:
Lhaineilhing (the lady who raised her hand in the photo) is a widow with four daughters. She sells vegetables in the village market. She does her business judiciously and with full commitment. 

In 2002, she mortgaged their house for her husband’s treatment, but he could not recover from his illness and died. Despite all these misfortunes, she conducts her daily business with enthusiasm. Customers love her and throng around her business place at all times. 

She saves some money from her earnings to get back her house. She wants to continue her vegetable business in a big way with the loan.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Galngam Lom Group

texts.en:
Lamshi (the one raising her hand in the photo) lives in Saikul, Manipur, India. She has three children. She sells daily-use products such as vegetables, sweets, and edible items in the marketplace every day. 

She is very concerned about her children’s education. For this, she struggles so hard and runs her small business with full dedication. The customers love her, which is a good sign for her business. 

She asks for a loan so that she can add more items in her business.

loans.use: to buy and add more items such as vegetables, sweets, and edible items in her business.

loans.name: Bharati

texts.en:
Bharati is a 38-year-old unmarried woman living with her brother. Her brother is married and has two children. She is a graduate and tutors some of the school-going children from her village in her house. She does not want to be a burden for her brother and wants to earn enough to be independent. 

Bharati wants to start a rice business in her village. She plans to purchase rice in the unprocessed form directly from the farmers and process the raw paddy grains to rice. She will go to the mill (processing house) which is very close to her house to get the processed rice grains. She plans to sell the processed rice in the village market. Her brother will help her in this business. 

Bharati has requested a loan of 40,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to purchase the unprocessed paddy grains. She also plans to spend a portion of her loan to build a warehouse to store the unprocessed paddy grains and processed rice product. She hopes to build a house of her own from the earnings of this business.

loans.use: to buy unprocessed rice grains and to build a warehouse for storing them

loans.name: Pramila

texts.en:
Pramila is a 41-year-old widow living with her two sons in the state of Odisha, India. Her younger son is in school and her elder one is a driver. Her elder son had to drop out of school to share the burden of the family with his mother. 

She runs a rice shop at her house on a small scale. Her monthly income from this business is 4000 Indian Rupees (INR). She says there is huge demand in her village as almost 50 families in the village buy rice from her and she sees a business opportunity in this demand. But she is not able to meet this demand due to a lack of stock, especially during the monsoon season when there is less supply available in the market. She wants to increase her stock of rice and her customer outreach to meet the demand especially during the monsoon season when she can get a better price. She wants to move her shop out of her house and have it in the market close to her house where she can get more customers. 

She has applied for a loan of 30,000 INR to rent a shop in a busy corner of the market and to stock up on more rice bags. She hopes that her younger son continues his education and becomes a good engineer.

loans.use: to rent a shop in a busy corner of the market and to buy more rice.

loans.name: Bilasini

texts.en:
Bilasini is a 50-year-old differently-abled lady. She is living with her husband and her two children. She has a poultry farm and two years of experience in this business. Her husband and children help her in this business. All the resources to run a poultry farm, including chicks, food, and medicines are provided by a popular meat-selling company in the market. She has to take care of the chicks and provide them shelter. They are collected by the company once they are grown big enough for meat. It is an interesting outsourcing business model. 

She currently has the capacity for 3000 chicks. The market demand for chicken is very high. So she wants to add more capacity to her farm for another 2000 chicks by extending the farm. 

She needs a loan of 50,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to add the extra capacity to her poultry farm. She says that if she invests 50,000 INR in this business then she can earn a good amount that will help her manage cash flows necessary to run the family and satisfy her customer demand.

loans.use: to buy more chicks for her poultry farm.

loans.name: Sri Ram Group

texts.en:
In 2009, six women from Muniguda village located in Rayagada district, one of the poorest regions in India, stepped out and decided to build a secure future for their family by sharing the burden of the family with their husbands. They formed a group named Sri Ram (named after Lord Rama who they believe will protect them). One of them is Lalita. The lady standing to the extreme left in the photo is Lalita. 

Lalita is 26 years old, living with her husband, two sons aged 9 and 6 and one daughter aged 5. All three of the children are attending school. Lalita started selling vegetables like tomatoes, potatoes, onions etc., and seasonal fruits like mangos and strawberries in the local village market with the help of her husband. Her husband has been involved in vegetable and fruit selling for the last 10 years. He brings stock from the nearby bigger markets which are 300-400 km away and sells to the local wholesalers in their village market. 

There was always some left-over stock that was not sold which had to be thrown away as they did not have a storage space of their own. So, Lalita decided to start selling these vegetables on her own by the roadside in the market. She now wants to rent a shop that will help her to have a place to sell the vegetables. It will also help her to buy more stock at a time and house the additional stock of vegetables. Buying more stock will help reduce her frequent travel to the market and eventually transportation and buying costs. A portion of the loan amount will help her to rent a shop in the market and purchase more stock of vegetables and fruits. She would like to grow her business and save enough to have a shop of her own.

loans.use: To rent a shop to sell her vegetables and fruits and buy more vegetables and fruits to stock

loans.name: Ganesh

texts.en:
Ganesh is 35-year-old differently-abled man living with his wife and two sons in Odisha, India. Earlier he worked as field staff with a non-governmental organization (NGO) on a contract basis. His contract with that NGO was completed in March 2012. 

Currently, he is unemployed and wants to start a new grocery business on his own. He has planned to keep personal care items like soaps, shampoos etc., daily household consumables like rice, and food items like biscuits in his grocery shop. 

He has requested a loan of 25,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to start his shop, so that he can provide a better life to his family and a good education to his children. He does not want his children's education to be stopped in the middle of their schooling.

loans.use: to buy items like soaps, shampoos, rice, and biscuits for his grocery shop.

loans.name: Matan

texts.en:
Matan is a 25-year-old differently-abled lady living with her parents, younger brother, and sister. She is the only one who financially supports her family. Her brother does not have any fixed source of income. He works in the paddy fields as a daily laborer which depends on the season. She runs a tailoring shop at a rented place in a good location in the market. She started with one sewing machine. She slowly involved her friend with some training in the business and grew to owning two sewing machines. Her business is growing with interest from other girls in the village eager to learn and get trained from her. She enjoys teaching what she knows and hopes to give other girls in her village a source of income. 

She has requested loan of 20,000 Indian Rupees (INR) from People's Forum to purchase two additional sewing machines and rent a room for training purposes. After some time she can appoint trainees as additional work staff to help her and eventually grow her business. She wants to give her family a good living standard and get her younger brother and sister well-educated to see them work for a multinational company (MNC).

loans.use: to buy two additional sewing machines and rent a room for giving training to her village girls.

loans.name: Sarojini

texts.en:
Sarojini is a 43-year-old woman living with her son, aged 22. She lost her husband in an accident in 2008. Since then she has been working hard to manage her family. She started a broilers (meat chicken) farm on a small piece of land that she owns with the help of her son. Meat chickens reared indoors reach slaughter weight at the age of three months and after three months she sells them to local meat shops. She currently has 2000 chicks on her farm and wants to buy 2000 more to meet the market demand. She says that there is a lot of demand for meat during the local festivals and auspicious wedding seasons. 

She needs a loan amount of 40,000 Indian Rupees (INR) to invest in buying the 2000 additional chicks, feed and medicine for them. She also plans to spend a major portion of her loan to construct a new shelter to house the additional chicks. This loan will help her to earn enough to construct a house of their own and arrange for her son's wedding.

loans.use: to buy additional chicks, feed, and medicine, and to construct a new shelter to house the additional chicks.

loans.name: Trinath Group

texts.en:
This group is called “Trinath” (named after the Hindu Lord Shiva, Vishnu and Brahma).Its four members are all women from a town called Muniguda. It is located in the district of Rayagada; one of the poorest districts in India. 

One of the members of this group is Sarada. The one raising her hand in the photo is Sarada. She is 44 years old, living with her husband, two sons aged 25 and 17 and one daughter aged 18. She has been running a grocery shop business in her village market with the help of her husband for the last 15 years. She sells items like rice, wheat, lentils, spices, cooking oil, biscuits, sodas, etc. She started off selling basic groceries like rice, lentils and wheat by the roadside and grew to owning a small shop with an increased variety of items. 

Sarada says there is a lot of demand as it is a huge market with almost 40 villages depending on this market and that she does not have enough stock to meet the demand. She does not like saying “No” to her customers and wants to be able to give best service to her customers. She now wants to buy more stock of what she is selling like rice, wheat, spices, etc. to increase her inventory level to be able to meet the demand and seize the business opportunity.

A portion of the loan will be utilized by her to purchase increased stock in bulk which will reduce her buying costs. She would like to build another room over the existing room to start a ladies' shoppe where she can sell bangles, nail polish and cosmetics. She hopes to save enough from her increased revenues for her daughter's wedding.

loans.use: To buy more stock of items like wheat, rice, lentils, spices, etc. for her grocery shop

loans.name: Gunasagar

texts.en:
Gunasagar is a 36-year-old differently-abled person living with his wife and two daughters aged five and two. He runs a variety shop where he sells betel, packaged foods, detergents and sodas. He earns 5000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month from this business, which is not sufficient for a family to live a happy life. 

He has applied for a loan of 30,000 INR for purchasing more of what he sells and adding new products like biscuits, wafers, engine oil, etc. (as it is not available in the radius of eight km from his village) to his shop. He wants to add daily household consumables and cosmetics to his shop. 

He has a dream that both his daughters work in a public sector unit and get married into a good family.

loans.use: to restock existing products like betel, packaged foods, detergents and sodas, and to add new products like biscuits, wafers, and engine oil

loans.name: Ganesh

texts.en:
Ganesh is a 30-year-old differently-abled man living with his wife and two children. He has been engaged in the business of mushroom cultivation, at very small scale, for the past two years. The local market sellers come and buy from him and sell at the market. He earns 7000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month from this business. 

Mushrooms are a very popular item used in cooking Indian curries in Odisha. The demand for mushrooms is very high in the market, but he is not able to meet that demand, so he decided to do this mushroom cultivation at a larger scale. 

He has requested a loan of 70,000 INR for purchasing mushroom seeds, compost, sterilized bags, and machinery for pasteurization. He will also hire an additional work force to help him to do it at larger scale. 

He says that he can save enough from the increased earnings to make a big house for his family and send his children to a good school.

loans.use: to buy mushroom seeds, compost, sterilized bags, and machinery for pasteurization, and to hire an additional work force for his mushroom business.

loans.name: Rajani

texts.en:
Rajani is a 34-year-old widow living with her son and daughter who are school-aged. She has had a tailoring business for the past two years. She has one sewing machine in her house and takes orders and make dresses for her customers. She earns 6000 Indian Rupees (INR) from this business per month. 

She wants to enhance her business by purchasing four new sewing machines and cloth for stitching in bulk. She needs a loan of 25,000 INR. She plans to increase her customer base by satisfying their needs. 

She wants to make her children well-educated and see them work in a good company.

loans.use: to buy four new sewing machines and fabrics for stitching in bulk.

loans.name: Nilendri

texts.en:
Nilendri is a 44-year-old widow living with her son and daughter-in-law. She runs a poultry farm in her village which is in Odisha, India. Her son helps her in her business, from which she earns 15,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. She sells these chickens to the butchers in the market near her village and even sometimes she sells directly from her poultry farm to the people who purchase chickens in bulk from her. 

She has requested a loan of 40,000 INR for purchasing more chicks and medicines for them. She wants to increase her client base. 

She has a very good relationship with her customers, as she fulfills their demand.

loans.use: to buy chicks and medicines for her poultry farm.

loans.name: Niranjan

texts.en:
Niranjan is a 30-year-old physically challenged person living with his wife and parents. He has been running an electronics repair shop in his village market for the last 10 years. He earns 3,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month. He repairs televisions, radios, fans, DVD players, and CD players. But he needs to go to the market to bring the required spare parts to repair these electronic machines as and when required. He does not have enough funds to have these spare parts in stock. As a physically challenged person it is difficult to go to the market very frequently and he is not able to provide fast service. He wants to purchase these spare parts in bulk and improve his customer service by reducing the turnaround time for the repairs. 

Niranjan has applied for a loan of 10,000 INR to purchase spare parts like picture tubes, sensors, remotes, lenses, etc., which are frequently needed in his repair work. This will help him do repairs quickly, provide better service to his customers, and attract more customers. He will also not have to go to the market very frequently. He says he will earn 6000 to 7000 INR per month from this business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts like picture tubes, sensors, remotes, lenses, etc., which are frequently needed in his electronics repair shop.

loans.name: Mahabina Group

texts.en:
Mahabina (The name of the Hindu Goddesses of Education) is a group of six active and energetic women from Muniguda village of Rayagada district in Odisha, India.  This group was started in the year 2010 with a purpose to raise the income level of their families.The featured member Sudeshna is one of them. The lady sitting to the extreme left raising her hand in the photo is Sudeshna. She is 40 years old, living with her husband and three sons aged 20, 18 and 16. All her sons are attending college. 

Sudeshna has been in the sweets-selling business with the help of her husband for the last 20 years. She makes six different types of locally popular sweets like Lavang Lata (fried dough dipped in sugar syrup with a clove on top), Gulab Jamun (fried round balls of dough dipped in sugar syrup), etc.  Her husband runs a sweet stall in the local market where he sells these products. They also supply to three local bakeries and for any other functions in their village. Sudeshna cooks for 6 hours over an open fire every day making 30-40 kg of sweets with a daily expenditure of Rs.2,000/-.

She needs to replenish her stock of raw materials like dough, oil, sugar, and firewood every three days. She says these raw materials are subject to price change very frequently and that she has been a victim of the price change many times due to her frequent replenishment cycle. A portion of the loan amount will be utilized by her to buy raw materials in bulk and store them to shield herself from price fluctuation losses. This will also help her to save the repeated transportation costs and buying costs.

Sudeshna wants to see her sons as respectable engineers and government employees in society. So she and her husband are working very hard to save enough for the education of their children. She has plans to invest her increased revenues to build a separate kitchen room to make it easier for the preparation of her sweets. 

Trupatimayi, Nirmala, Purnabasi, Sumati and Gauri are the other five members of the group who are involved in businesses like tailoring, leaf plate making, auto repair shop, etc. They are all very hard-working and enjoy the group interaction with a good understanding amongst them.

loans.use: To buy more stock of raw materials like sugar, dough, and cooking oil for her sweets business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 46-years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Region of Uganda. She is married and has three children. For the past 20 years, Agnes has been working hard to manage her food stall, where she sells bananas, spices and other foods. 

To help expand her business, Agnes has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock like beans and vegetables to sell, and will help Agnes to generate greater profits that will help her reach her goal of starting up a charcoal business in the future. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Agnes who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stock like beans and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en:
Phally is 36-years old and married. She lives with her husband and three children in a rural village. One of her children is still in school while the others have their own employment. She is a fried banana and cassava seller in her local area while her husband helps support her business. She has been in this business for ten years earning about 11,000 KHR per day. 

This is the second loan for Phally's group of two. She successfully used the first micro loans to relieve her family's financial burden and improve their livelihood. Now, she is leading another member to apply for a loan of 500,000 KHR each. She will use her portion to buy bananas and cassava for her business and use a portion of it to buy some ingredients. She hopes to increase her current business to earn more income to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy banana and cassava for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise such as torches, scissors, remote controls, knives, etc.

loans.name: Ana Luisa

texts.es: Ana Luisa de 33 años, es una madre de familia muy responsable y trabajadora, vive en zona marginal en casa muy sencilla, se dedica al oficio de la agricultura de maíz, actividad que realiza junto a su esposo e hijos, para poder obtener algunas ganancias extras, Ana también trabaja como empleada domestica, haciendo lavadas y planchadas de ropa visitando casas de clientes 3 veces por semana, tratando de ayudar a su esposo en la economía del hogar. Ella solicita un préstamo a INTEGRAL, con el deseo de comprar fertilizante para las semillas y así producir mayor calidad en su productos y de esta forma contar con más clientes, lo que es muy importante para ella ya que de esta manera aumentará sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Ana Luisa, 33, is a very hard-working and responsible wife and mother. She lives in an underprivileged area, in a very simple house.  Together with her husband and children, she grows corn for a living. To earn extra money, Ana also does domestic work, visiting her clients’ homes three times a week to do their washing and ironing. This is Ana’s way of helping her husband to provide for the family. 

Ana has applied for a loan from INTEGRAL, with which she plans to buy fertiliser for her seeds, in the hope that this will improve the quality of her products. She hopes that this, in turn, will win her more customers and increase her income, which is very important to her.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Chantha's Group

texts.en:
